string.text: Inowrocław Castle
Skotniki is located in west Pomerania. The land here is not especially rich, but is sufficient for the raising of sheep.
Stargarder Castle
Vielist sits just north of the Mecklenburg Lakeland, close to the Kölpinsee. The local population enjoys sermons at a small stone church.
Gravensteen Castle
Amblève

Amblève, or Amel lies on the road from Metz to Cöln. Ruins of an old Roman villa are situated nearby and it is thought that the Romans used to wade the nearby rivers in search of gold, a practice that is still done by the locale today but without great success.
Burghausen Castle
Moosthenning sits in a broad valley in the south on the frontier of the Alps. Nomadic herders once occupied this land, and the villagers today still raise cattle.
Anhalt Castle
Langelege in the valley of the Aller, a cold, slow-moving river that splits from the river Weser. The level, wet land here is fine for the growing of flax.
Habsburg Castle
Schönbrunn

Schönbrunn sits south of the Neckar valley. The settlement consists of two villages, Unter and Oberschönbrunn. The people of this area are skilled at finding seams of silver ore exposed by the streams rushing down from the mountains.
Budatín Castle
Curovitz lies in the far east of the Empire. The region is relatively thinly populated, but large herds of cattle graze on the green downs.
Walkaz is one of the southernmost settlements of Germany. The region is relatively thinly populated, but large herds of cattle graze on the green downs.
Český Šternberk Castle

Cretes or Střítež, meaning 'near the reeds', lies on the northern banks of the Markovka stream which flows into a nearby reservoir. On a hill to the south is a homely church that the pious local populace has weekly sermons in.
Mailan lies on a hilly high plateau and is characterized by forest and moor landscapes, farmland and numerous granite formations that give the surrounding landscape a rustic character.
Wartburg Castle
Wurzbach sits overlooking the Franconian Forest on its northwestern edge, on the river Somitz. The village thrives on the ore deposits exposed where the cataract cuts through the escaparment.

Heslinga sits near the river Oste, at one of its more narrow points. The hamlet is accompanied by a Roman styled stone church, which is part of the local monastery. The village had seen better days, however, as their granting of market rights by the Salian Emperor Konrad II had been revoked a hundred years later.
Gdańsk

The city of Gdańsk is located on the Gulf of Gdańsk, at the mouth of the river Motława to the river Vistula and is one of the largest settlements found in Pomerania. It was once part of Western Pomerania until Bolesław III Krzywousty was victorius in the war with the Pomeranians and Leszek Biały's expeditions caused Polish suzerainty to be established over what is now Gdańsk Pomerania
Lascovic lies right next to a small lake with which it shares its name. The villagers here are skilled miners, extracting iron ores from the surrounding cliffsides.
Dargocice lies east of Lake Kamienica. The highland streams wash fertile soil down the hillsides, making this district one of the breadbaskets of the Pomeranian lands.
Koblyniz
Koblyniz is a quiet fishing village on the northern seashores of Pomerania. The river Słupia flows along the eastern outskirts and villagers harvest pike from its waters.
Héverlé
Héverlé lies in the Dyle valley and is surrounded by vast forests. The village has a modest church dedicated to Saint Anne, the mother of the virgin Mary.

Hamburg is at a sheltered natural harbour, between continental Europe to the south and Scandinavia to the north, with the North Sea to the west and the Baltic Sea to the northeast. The river that runs through the city is the Elbe. Its name comes from a castle that Charlemagne odered constructed here named Hammaburg.
Eddelak lies near the entrance of the Niederelbe Bay, on the north western end of the German lands. The folk of this region live well off the pike and bream of the river.
Holthusen sits in meadowland in the northern reaches of Europe. The climate, kept mild by the lake breezes, makes for good horse breeding.

Lichtenberg sits between foothills of three nearby mountains, the Reiherberg, the Steinberg and the Eichberg. The village saw its foundation by the building of the church by bishop Benno von Meißen. Cattle are raised here in former marshy woodlands, now drained and turned into meadows.
Cöln

Cöln sits on a low pass leading from the Nevys valley to the north to the pool of the Ophthys. The ancient Palaic peoples of this region, like the English, treated lakes as sacred sites, and the Ophthys in particular was said to be a gateway to another world. The hustle and bustle of Cöln, one of the main trading centers of inland Calradia, stands in sharp contrast to the dark and silent waters below.
Astonfelde sits about a half days' travel from Cöln. The name of the village means 'field in the east'.

Postrquino sits on the site where there was once a fortified settlement. The stronghold was burnt down near a hundred years in the past, and Postrquino rose from its ashes. The village is bordered by a lake, from which a small stream runs past the village.
Moltberghe lies in the northern reaches of the German lands. The highland soils make fine grazing for horses and its proximity to the Germanic Sea brings warm summers and mild winters.

The city of Wien is located at the easternmost extension of the Alps and just south of the meandering Danube. Its surroundings have known continuous habitation for centuries. At some point in time, the Romans fortified this frontier city which they called Vindobona to guard the empire against the Germanic tribes to the north. In 1221, Wien received the Stapelrecht, which means that all traders passing through are obliged to offer their goods in the city. This has allowed the city to act as middleman in trade, controlling vast networks of far-reaching trade relations along the Danube basin. Today it is one of the most important cities in Germany.

The hamlet of Willenruit is located just south of a large forest, where a chapel can be found. The people of these parts have raised cattle since pre-Roman times, and its milk and butter are sought out by traders and travellers passing through the region.
Gönyű

Gönyű lies on the flat southern banks of the river Danube. The waters of the river, which are very shallow and muddy here, are well-stocked with flounder and crayfish, while trout can be fished further upstream.

Ahlbeck is a fishing village to the south of the Pomeranian lagoon, near the marches of the Polish Principalities. Villagers plac nets and cages in the shallow edges of the lake to catch roach, bream, perch, and crayfish.

Ybbsitz sits in the Ybbs valley and by the 'Kleine Ybbs', a smaller stream of the Ybbs river. The locals recommend hiking the nearby reaches of the Ybbstal alps, and some have even reported that one can see 'moving stars' shooting across the skies during summer nights.

Praha gets it name from the Slavic word for 'ford' or 'rapid', which refers to the town's origin at a crossing point of the Vltava river. Praha is an important seat for trading where merchants from across all Europe have settled.
Lalling sits in the southwest of the Bavarian Forest. The lands are largely tied to the nearby monastery of Niederaltaich.
Perlesreut sits in the Bavarian Forest between two river valleys. The hamlet is bound to a small, very old castle nearby.
Bayerbach lies in frontier Alpine country of the German heartland. The grasses on the rolling downs are well-suited to the raising of sheep.

Elbogen lies mostly in the Kaiserwald, or the Emperor's Forest. It is situated partly on a hill, and the river Eger that flows through it is where the village gets its name from - it is shaped like an elbow, or 'elbogen' in German.

The area around Straborc was always inhabited by various peoples; Celtic and then Germanic tribes until the Romans arrived and erected a fortified military camp. Over time, it grew into a city and grew in importance. It was invaded on multiple occasions and remained under tumultous control between Germanic tribes and the Romans until it was eventually destroyed by forces under Atilla the Hun. Only a hundred years later would it be founded again, and developed relatively peacefully and under the Merovingians Straborc became a royal city. Today, it stands far above its former glory and with repaired Roman enclosures, two large cathedrals, hospital and well over ten thousand inhabitants it is now one of the largest in the German states.

The marcher village of Telsperg sits on the banks of the river Sorne, just before it flows into the river Birs. These lands have been inhabited for centuries. Its name is a combination of the Germanic name Tallo with the latin word for mountain, 'mons'. The French call this village Deleymont.
Spangen-Dahlem actually consists of two smaller villages that grew next to eachother, Spang and Dahlem. The surrounding landscape is characterized by large stretching fields.
Burgos Castle

Osorno lies on the southern shores of the Valdavia and the Boedo confluence in the northern hinterlands of the Iberian peninsula. Meadows where tall grasses tolerant of the ocean salt-spray thrive, support the rearing of fine horses.
Bragança Castle
Bragança

Bragança sits on the banks of the Fervença, a smaller river than its northern neighbour, the Sabor. Located in the northern frontiers of Portugal, river irrigation and the relatively warm inland climate ensure that the grain fields of this district feed much of the local population.

Braga just south of the Cávado River and the landscape here is characterized by irregular valleys, interspersed by mountainous spaces, fed by rivers running in parallel with the principal rivers. River irrigation and the relatively warm inland climate ensure that the grain fields of this district, along with neighboring Bragança, feed much of the central kingdom.
Valongo Castle

Batalha lies on the mouth of the river Sado, where it flows into the Setúbal bay and into the north Atlantic. The hills of this district are terraced with the olive groves for which the region is famous, producing a light, fragrant oil.
Larache Castle

Bayyana sits on the eastern banks of the Almería river, bordering forest of holm oaks. These lands, stirred by hot winds from the south and watered by hillside springs, have been used by imperial landowners for the experimental growing of date palms.
León Castle

Benavente was founded as a settlement of foreign settlers on the south bank of the Tagus, and the village as well as many surrounding lands belong to the Order of Calatrava. On summer nights the hills above the village are dotted with the fires of shepherds, taking their animals to graze on the upland pastures.
Villalazán
Villalazán sits in warm, oak-covered hills on the southern slopes of the meandering Douro. Sheep-raising is a way of life in these parts, as is sheep-rustling.
Badajoz Castle

The hamlet of Arronches lies in the eastern frontier lands of Portugal, north of the Rio Caia which winds through the hilly landscape. Villagers grow olives on the slopes of the characteristically hilly terrain.
Zorita Castle

Nohales sits a short walk north of the river Júcar, which has a handful of smaller streams springing northwards. Early morning sea-mists from the west and the hot sun of midday allow the growing of wine grapes.
Huérmeda

Huérmeda is situated downstream of the Jalón River, on its right embankments. On the mountain that rises on the opposite side of the river is the hermitage of the Saint Paterno, who brought the Gospel to this region. Olive trees grow on the slopes of the nearby hills, warmed by the southern sun.
Biniés Castle

Alcoletge sits in the gorges of the Segre river, a tributary tot he Ebro. The landscape here is predominantly flat. Villagers have sunk mines into a spur that overlooks the village, extracting silver and other precious metals.

Valencia is located on the eastern coast of the Iberia and the western part of the Mediterranean Sea, fronting the Gulf of Valencia. The city lies on highly fertile alluvial silts on the floodplain formed in the lower course of the river Turia. At its founding by the Romans, the town stood on a river island in the Turia about four miles from the sea. It was a colony when it was founded by the Romans, and in the 8th century Islamic rule and acculturation ensued. Christian conquest took place in 1238, and the city was surrendered to an army of Aragonese, Catalans, Navarrese and crusaders from the Order of Calatrava. Fifty thousand Moors were forced leave and Valencia was returned to to Spanish rule.'

Cocentaina lies in a very irregular landscape, with numerous ravines on the eastern slope of the Sierra de Mariola that drain into the Serpis River. Pigs, fed on the acorns of the southern oak trees, thrive in this climate.
Constantí

The village of Constantí sits in Catalonia, surrounded by small streams that originate from the Francolí, which flow from south to north past the village. The foresters here keep a watchful eye on their neighbors, always looking for raiding parties coming westward from the valley of the Llobregat river to their east.
Almadén

Almadén, from 'al-ma'din' in Arabic, sits on a low-lying meander of one of hundreds of small streams originating from Lake Castilserás, in the shadow of the plutonic Sierra Almadén. Flax grows in fields reclaimed from the river marshlands.

Lisboa sits by the seaside on the right embankment of the Tagus estuary on the western Portuguese coast of the Atlantic. An old legend states that the city of Lisboa was founded by the Greek hero Odysseus and that, like Rome, its original settlement was surrounded by seven hills. In Roman times, the city was famous for its manufacture of Garum, a luxury food made from fish paste which was preserved in amphorae and exported to Rome and throughout the empire. Annals of the city tell of a Viking raid somewhere in the middle of the eight century on the city's coast consisting of six ships and hundreds of men and women, who raided the nearby coastal villages for two weeks before they were repelled.
Portela sits on the southern embankments of the Odeleite river in the southern Portuguese hinterlands. The sandy soil and morning mists allows the growing of grapes overlooking the river slopes.
Caranguejeira, sits in gently sloping land in the heartlands of Portugal. The local landowners have established stud farms, supplying horses to the kingdom's cavalry.
Alcanhões

Alcanhões sits in western hinterlands of Portugal. There are remains of old Roman bathhouses in the northern part of the hamlet. Though the climate is relatively dry here, artesian wells allow farmers to grow bountiful crops of wheat.

Reguengo at the foot of the Serra de São Mamede, a mountain range named after Saint Mammes of Caesarea that separates the drainage basin of the Tagus to the north from the basin of the Guadiana to the south. Though the climate is relatively dry here, artesian wells allow farmers to grow bountiful crops of wheat.

Ishbiliya sits in the fertile valley of the Guadalquivir river, mostly on its left banks although some neighbourhoods are on the right banks making the city a fluvial port. The surrounding landscape is characterized by a rich plain, countryside and marshland. The mythological founder of the city of Ishbiliya is Hercules who, according to legend, sailed through the Gibraltar passage to the Atlantic and founded trading posts at the current site of Ishbiliya.
Shalubīnya

Shalubīnya sits at the southern Iberian coast in Andaluza, bordered on the west by rugged terrain, east by the valley of the Guadalfeo river and northeast by the Sierra de los Guájares mountains. The wines of this region are unusually sweet and strong, and valued throughout the Empire.

Arriadh, in the Andaluza region, sits in the middle of a dozen or so small streams that all meander the landscape. Though known for the goats that used to roam this region, the landowners have turned over the pastures to the raising of far more profitable horses.
Alcolaya sits by a bend of the Guadalquivir in the heart of Andaluza. Villagers divert the mountain streams to irrigate their rich grainfields.
Barçalona

The founding of the city of Barçalona has many legends. Legends speak of founding by the mythological Hercules, other legends attribute the founding to the Carthaginian general Hamilcar Barca, father of Hannibal, who supposedly named the city after his family. The city is located on the northeastern Spanish coast where it faces the Mediterranean Sea, sitting on a wide plain limited by the Collserola mountain range and the rivers Llobregat and Besòs.

Armentera sits on the southern embankment of the river Fluvià, in windy hinterlands of the eastern Iberian coast. The sides of the hills are terraced to grow wheat, with cisterns to catch the rain blowing up from the sea.
Fontellas lies just on a bend of the river Ebro, near broad banks where the villagers make a living fishing for perch, bass and carp.

Vinela lies in the eastern Iberian hinterlands on the river Ebro, next to a fluvial island on its right bank and about a days walk from where it flows into the Mediterranean Sea. Villagers trek eastwards to collect salt from the sea in the shadow of coastal cliffs.
Coll de Nargó
Coll de Nargó lies near a rich vein of silver in hills overlooking the Segre river. The Spanish have minted its coins from these mines for centuries.

Santiago, in northwestern Galicia, finds it origin in the shrine of Saint James the Great who according to legend brought Christianity to the people of Iberia. This shrine stands today as the monumental Cathedral of Santiago, as destination of the Way of Saint James which is one of the major routes of pilgrimage in Europe. When the remains of the apostle James were brought here for burial, the light of a bright star guided a shepherd who was watching his flock at night to the burial site located on the very place where the cathedral was ordered to be built by King Alfonso II following this discovery.

Luarca sits on the northern Iberian shore in Asturias, at the mouth of the Rio Negro where it flows into the Cantabrian Sea. These sunny, well-watered coastlands are one of the breadbaskets of the Iberia.
Carneros sits amid rolling chalk hills in the northwest of Castile, by the river Tuerto. The rich grass of the down is some of the best horse-breeding land in the Empire.

The city of Madrid was founded by the Cordobese Emir Muhammad I, who ordered a fortress built on a headland near the river Manzanares, as one of the many fortresses between Al-Andalus and the kingdoms of León and Castile with the objective of protecting Toledo from the Christian invasions. The city was seized in 1083 by Alfonso VI, who sought to use it as offensive outpost against Toledo. Since 1188, the city of Madrid was granted rights to be a city in the courts of Castile. About sixty miles south of the Guadarrama mountain range, Madrid originally grew on the left banks of winding Manzanares and continues to expand eastwards.
Torreorgaz lies in the wooded highlands north of the River Salor. The villagers raise cattle in the highland pastures.

Jaca lies between the interior mountains of the Pyrenees, on a plateau next to the river Aragón, which heads west through the Berdún channel. The villagers mine iron from shafts sunk deep into the cliffs of the mountains.
El Frontil
El Frontil, from the Arabic 'al-Funtayn', sits in the shadow of Mount Hacho, a low mountain that overlooks the the north coast of Africa. This district is one of the grain breadbaskets of Andaluz.
Membrilla sits on the La Mancha plateau, around the snaking river Azuer that flows into the river Guadiana further downstream. This district is one of the grain breadbaskets in Castile.
Triorae Castle
Quiliano is located in a hinterland valley, on the left bank of the fertile plain bordering a river stream. The valley is part of the mountains Burot and Baraccone.
Padenghe Castle
Pizzano is a small hamlet situated in the Alps. To the west, there is a large valley green with vast grass meadows, crossed by a small stream that flows into the river Adige.

Galedum is the lies on the southern reaches of the Alps in the frontier lands of the Italian peninsula. The hamlet, established in more peaceful times, is a center for mulberry bushes used in silk production.
Sant'Angelo Castle

Toritto lies in a narrow valley in the south of Italy. Villagers here cultivate mulberry bushes. The leaves are harvested and fed to silkworks, producing thread much valued by both refined Italian nobles for their courtwear and hard-riding nomads and frontiersmen, who wear it beneath their armor as an extra layer of protection against arrows.
San Brancato

The village of San Brancato was once a Roman colony, and the surrounding lands have inhabited even centuries before the Romans. The silver mined from nearby hills helps explain the effort and expense to which the kingdom of Sicily has gone in past centuries to conquer and defend these lands.
Covasina Castle

The hamlet of Cecina is situated near the end of the Valley of Cecina, near the mouth of the river with the same name. The land is mostly flat. Local legend has it that the first king of the Visigoths, Alaric, passed these lands once—which were devastated after recent looting by Goths—and contracted a grave illness that ultimately brought an end to his life.

Paganico is a small hamlet located at the confluence of a large river, on a stream called the Lanzo. The area is mostly flat and sees cultivation of crops near the river. The village is planned to be fortified, as it sits on a strategic position of the river valley as an opening towards the sea.
Langobardia Castle
The hamlet of Scandali is located on a hilltop between the Ionian Sea and the mountains of Sila.

Dissertina lies on the highest step of the Rhine valley, where the roads of the Oberalp pass and the Lukmanier pass meet. Some say the vultures for which the rock is named once gathered here to feast on the bodies of those who died working the local silver mines.
Sarnes Castle
Mallnitz lies in a side valley to the left of the river Möll, and is embedded in two large massifs.

The hamlet Laurino lies about sixty miles southeast of the city of Napoli. It is situated on the top of a hill, dominating the surrounding landscape. The ruins of an old Lombard castle can be found only a short walk to the north, outside the village.

Ancona can find the history for its name from the Greeks of Syracuse, who founded the city centuries ago and noticed the particular shape of the promontory, which was similar to a bent elbow. Thus, 'Ankón'—meaning 'elbow' in Greek—was founded. The city iself rises on the central Adriatic coast, on the northern slopes of the Mount Conero, the elbow-shaped promontory. The urban area is characterized by an alternation of hills and valleys.
Baiardo sits in the Armea valley on one of the mountain ridges of the Alps. The territory is mainly composed of olive groves.
Posta sits among northern end of the Velino gorges, along the course of the river with the same name. The environment is typically mountainous, bordering the Terminillo massif.
Porziano sits just west of the city of Ancona. It is among the many settlements of the area that dates back to Roman times, its name said to be taken after the Roman god Janus.

Casoli is perched on a hill to the right of the Aventino river, at the foot of the Maiella massif. At the beginning of the 10th century, a community of hermit monks of the Greek Rite of Constantinople settled here.

Written in the Chronicon Altinate is that Venezia started as a mythical settlement dating back to AD 421, with the consecration of the church of San Giacometo. Much like in Roman times, Venezia remains a popular getaway location for the nobility.

The village of Troina has been settled since the time of the Greeks, as evidenced by ruins of walls from the Greek town and baths built by the Romans that once inhabited it too. Not far from the village stands a castle which had been used by Ruggero I as his start base of his conquest of the island of Sicilia.
The dark, well-watered soil of Baura makes this region a breadbasket for the kingdom. The name is deriven from the word 'boaria' which refers to the breeding of livestock.
Šentrupert

Šentrupert lies in a valley in the southern hills of the Carinthian lands. The river Bistrica flows through this valley, which joins the river Nirine. The surrounding mountains allows for favorable weather and the dark, well-watered soil here makes this region a veritable breadbasket.

Monticolum lies on the southern coast of the Histrian peninsula, on a hill that dominates the southwest. Though fishing is poor in these parts, villagers have constructed salt pans that stick far out into the shallow waters.

The town of Palermo sits near the northern shores of the Perassic Sea. The warm rolling hills of these parts are well suited to the raising of sheep and horses. The herdsmen have a reputation for being proud and violent, but the nobles of the Leonipardes clan who rule this land are careful to respect their autonomy. Livestock rustling and blood feuds are common here, and it is said that the Leonipardes will never interfere unless invited by both parties, but when they do, their judgments will be obeyed by all.
Serra del Falco

Serra del Falco is a relatively young village, having been founded under rule of the Kingdom of Sicily. Its name means 'Mountain of the Falcon'. Local legend says that many falcons once nested in the surrounding rocky heights and thus one of these cliffs was named Serra del Falcone.

With the arrival of the Normans in Calabria in the 11th century, Cirifarco had been made a feudal fief. Its central position on the narrowest point of the peninsula makes Cirifarco a point of strategic value and, the late King of Sicily Frederick II was known to practice his love for falconing in these lands. On a hill to the north-west lies a fortified structure that was built by the Swabians after the sixth crusade.
Partanna sits where the plains of Sicily meet the coastal hills. Sheep graze on the low slopes overlooking the hazy flatlands.

Roma, or Rome, the famous capital of Italy and the former heart of the greatest empire in Europe. Originally the city was developed on the famous seven Roman hills that faced onto a ford of the river Tiber. Since the fall of the Roman Empire, the city has been in the hands of many different kingdoms and rulers. Roma is also considered to be a important site for Christian pilgrims who visit, among other historic sites, the Vatican.
The village of Pontecorvo is found in one of the rockier and less fertile parts of the country, but the valley scrubs still supports the grazing of sheep.

Capannole is a village located in the northeastern part of the Tuscan region. The area has most likely been inhabited since the time of the Romans, as ruins nearby are thought to be hundreds of years old.

Napoli is the intellectual centre of the Kingdom of Sicily home to the famous University of Naples. Founded by Emperor Frederick II, it was the first university in all of Europe dedicated to training secular administrators. The city is situated on the Bay of Naples, on the western coast of the Italian peninsula. Legend says the Roman emperor Caligula had once built a bridge of boats across the bay and rode across it in a chariot while wearing the armor of Alexander the Great.
Cerina originated as the Norman village of Ceriniola built on the ashes of an ancient settlement.
Pietrapulcina is located on a humble hill, bordering the river Tammarino on its eastern side which is known to be the king Manfred's favourite river in all of the kingdom.

Caprino is located in the southeast of the Italian peninsula, not far from the coast. North of it lies a large lake that is separated from the Adriatic sea by a very narrow land line that is covered with primarily pines and eucalyptus trees. It borders a forest to the south and the surrounding territory is mainly hilly.

The city of Genova sits in the central part of gulf and overlooks the Ligurian Sea, between the coast and reliefs of the Ligurian-Genoese Apennines. The reliefs that surround the city block the cold winds from the north, which allows for relatively sunny and bright winters.

Vinca is located in a valley on the northern slopes of the Apuan Alps. To the east, the peak of the mountain Pizzo d'Uccello can be seen. Some stories of the foundation of Vinca trace back to the period of the raids by the Moors, whom built this small community after fleeing inland from the coast.
Bovegno and its surroundings are dominated by mountains, such as the Mount Crestoso and the Mount Muffetto.
Gatinèra

Gatinèra lies on the ridges of the Alps, bordered to the east by the river Sesia. The surrounding territories have seen intense phases of occupation since the Roman age. The route along the Sesia river has been one of the busiest for generations, as it serves as a link between the plain and the roads leading to the Alpine passes.
Cagliari sits on the southern shore of the island Sardegna. The city is located on a fantastic strategic point, between the sea and a fertile plain surrounded by marshland.
The village of Osilo and its surrounding areas have been inhabited for a long time. The village is located quite high, and a castle is being built on its highest hill.
Castiadas is a fishing village near the southern coast of the island of Sardegna. Huge pike can sometimes be found in the rivers, along with more common perch and bream.
Vrebac sits on the foot of a large mountain, with the river Jadova flowing through it. This low-lying country is fine land for the growing of flax.
Bergenhus Fortress
Vigmostad sits on the shores of the Skarpesvingen. Hardy northern cattle have been bred to eat the short grasses that grow among the rocks, supplemented by sea-kelp in hard times.
Otta Castle

Hedalen sits in the valley after which it is named after, the Hedalen. The area is characterized by coniferous forest. Villagers grow flax in the muddy valleys between the hills in this cold, rainy land.
Örebro Castle
Götafors
The lands around Götafors are cold, but the runoff from the hills brings rich soil, and villagers grow hardy crops like rye and barley.
Rönneshytta

Rönneshytta sits on pastures in a narrow passage between two lakes, the Malten and the Löcknasjön. Horses graze on the heights, glancing down occasionally at the trading longships and fishing boats passing beneath them.
Linköping Castle

Hjortkvarn sits in a broaded forested valley looking down on the lake Avern. The villagers in these parts are expert trappers, hunting marten, fox and rabbit for the rich pelts much in demand in the south.

Ismilkorg sits on grassy downs between the Galcha and Vastra rivers, two small tributaries of the Miron. The people here are mostly cattle-herders as well as cattle-rustlers, and have long traded raids with the imperial frontier villages to the east and English to the west.
Lindesberg sits near a small lake, Lindesjön. The surrounding forest, the ore and the fertile soil in the area are important factors when the area was chosen for settlement.
Djurås

Djurås lies at the meeting of the rivers Österdalälven and Västerdalälven. It serves as a base for traders venturing deeper into the woods, brave cold, wolves and the sometimes-hostile, sometimes-friendly peoples of the woods in pursuit of fur, the bounty of the northlands.
Sveg Castle
Rätansbyn

Rätansbyn is a cattle raising village at a pass near a lake that shares its name, the Rätansjon. It is one of the main trading and raiding routes between the wild north and the more settled heartlands.
Hindsgavl Castle
Uggerby sits near the northern Danish coast. Villagers net small spiny perch and crayfish in the shallow waters, drying them for sale to travellers.
Mynttornet Castle

Vladiv sits at the base of Mount Iltan, in a cold, dark wooded valley. The hardy cattle of this region have learned to dig through thick winter snows in search of grass to sustain them until the spring.

Vossavangen is a large village, a joining of the hamlets Voss and Vangen and sits on the eatern shores of the lake Vangsvatnet. The village boasts an old church, named Vangskyrkja. Legend says Olav's Cross on Vangen was erected by Olav the Saint.
Fåberg
Fåberg sits among rye and barley fields next to the Gudbrandsdal river, on the edge of valley Gudbrandsal. The village thrives on the grain it sells to the woodland fur-trapping communities.
Matre lies alongside the Fens fjord, where the local fishermen take advantage of the relatively sheltered waters of the bay, where fish of many kinds come to spawn.

Oslo, which sits on the icy waters of Mazopor bay, was founded by migrants from the Nordlands. Legend holds that the initial wave of Nords arrogantly demanded tribute from the nearby Vakken and Swedish tribes, who formed an alliance and drove the newcomers back to their ships. But the victors fell out over the spoils, until a canny Nord, Gundar, landed and volunteered to help them fairly divvy up the weapons and armor of his dead kinsmen. The residents recognized Gundar's lordship over the region and his descendants, intermarried with the Swedish, are today the grand princes of Sweden.
Miland sits on a high ridge overlooking the rapids that link the river Måna to Lake Tinnsjå. Villagers rear cattle on the grassy shelfs overlooking the sea-cliffs.
Kvelde borders a high rocky hill known as Jordstøyp in the Numedal valley. This harsh land would probably not be settled where it not for the rich iron deposits in the hills.
Tandsjöborg

Tandsjöborg is a small fishing village between the two castles at Sveg and Mora, and is surrounded by many small lakes. Villagers make their way down these lakes at dawn to catch salmon leaping over the rocks, as well as pike and perch.
Lödöse

Lödöse sits on the eastern shores of the Kattegatt. The town's location at the mouth of the Göta älv river, which feeds into the Kattegatt, has helped it grow as a trading city. The archipelago it sits on consists of rough, barren rocks and cliffs which are characteristic for the coastal region here. Some years ago, Birger Jarl hosted the Norwegian prince Hakon in the great hall of the city.
Odewall is located by a fjord at the mouth of the river Bäveån. The villagers grow rye and barley in fields misted by the spray from the falls.
Fammarp sits on a promontory jutting out over the northern part of the Laholm Bay. Villagers pull both freshwater flatfish from the shallow bay waters and bigger catch, including pike, from the sea.

It is said that Stockholm was founded by Birger Jarl to protect Sweden from the sea invasions of the Karelian raiders after they had pillaged the town of Sigtuna. Today it is not only the largest city in all of Sweden, but also considered to be the royal residence and political centre. Stockholm lies on Sweden's eastern coast, where the freshwater Lake Mälaren flows out into the Baltic Sea.
Örbyhus

Örbyhus sits on a small rise in the steep northern hilland of Stockholm. The village depends primarily on fishing, pulling perch, bream, salmon and occasionally large sturgeon and pike from the lake waters.
Nykvarn lies just south-west of Stockholm. The villagers in this district raise hogs, curing their fat with salt and in garlic and selling it at Stockholm's weekly markets.
Kungsgården
Kungsgården sits in a nook on the north shores of the lake Storsjön. Villagers here have found iron ore deposits in the mountainsides.

Åre sits at the southern foot of the mountain Åreskutan and on the northern shores of Lake Åresjön in the Jämtland region. The deep and large wide-open valley is surrounded by spruce forest, calf mountains and sloping meadows. Thousands of pilgrims from all over Europe visit the town's old church during their journey to the grave of Olof the Saint in the cathedral at Nidaros.
Sösjö

Sösjö is a sheep-rearing village just below to the south of Åre town. Though this region is cold and remote, its importance as a trade juncture between Åre and the southern Swedish estates, between the cold north and the heartlands, mean that it is relatively densely populated.
Bergsjö
Bergsjö sits between Lake Älgeredssjön and Lake Storsjön. Villagers raise highland cattle here, bred to withstand the icy gusts that tear down the mountain.
Nørre Broby

Nørre Broby is a small hamlet on the island Fyn. It houses a small Roman styled church and an old bridge that has been here for generations and has needed many repairs over the years. Villagers cultivate rye and barley on the high ground overlooking the lakes, and the rich black soil of the region compensates for the long winters and short growing season.
Örnsköldsvik
Örnsköldsvik sits on a natural harbour and archipelago in the Gulf of Bothnia in the chilly north of Sweden.

The villagers of Stugun raise small, sturdy cattle at the base of the Strömsnäs lake. They include the descendants of refugees and malcontents from across Scandinavia, seeking isolation in the cold northern forests.
Sollefteå
Sollefteå sits in a basin amid the river Ångermanälven. Villagers here grow flax in the marshy valley floor.

Ramvik sits deep in the forests of northeastern Sweden. This isolated region has long been a refuge for those fleeing oppression or debt or bloodfeud across the northlands, and the dialect is strongly influenced by the tongue of the Finnic woodspeople.

Køpmannæhafn, meaning 'merchant's harbour', is the largest settlement on the island Siâland. The town is said to have been founded by Sweyn Forkbeard, the Danish King that had once invaded Britain and crowned himself King of the English. The city centre is mostly flatlands while the surroundings to the north and west are hilly.
Hvallinge sits near the Ørasund strait. Villagers fish the waters to the west for cod, char, and other cold-water sea fish that venture into the bay.
Osby sits at a the mouth of the river Driveån, where it gets its name from; 'Os' meaning 'opening'. The humble village consists of a church, a dozen farmhouses and some crofts.

Engesland is a fishing village at the northern banks of the river Engeslandsåna, which flows into a lake further east, the Ljosevatnet. Villagers brave the waters of the lake to pull up ample catches of trout, pike, perch and many hope for the prized catch that is the Arctic char.
Nalut Castle
Bani Hasan
Bani Hasan lies on the northern Mediterannean coast of Libya. Villagers go fishing here amid the offshore islands in search of tuna, sardines, and shark.
Tawrirt Fortress
Zaïo
Zaïo is located on the fertile plain of Sebra. The nearby ridges catches rainclouds coming off the Mediterranean Sea, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.
Jar Issafen

Jar Issafen lies in the northeast of Morocco, bordering the Middle Atlas mountains to the south. Villagers trap floods running down the hills during rare rainstorms, using the water to grow date palms and other crops.
Amegdul Castle

The village of Shishawah is located near Marrakech. It gets its name from the nearby Mount Shishawah, which springs a river that flows past the village. The surrounding lands, though dry, produce enough grass in the spring to allow the breeding of horses.

Mazighan sits on the windswept southern shores of the sea that the Marinid call the Atlantic, which they named after the Atlas mountains that dominate the region. Villagers trap run-off water from the hills and grow flax in the lowlands here.
Sfaks Castle
Graïba

Medeni sits in the south of the Tunisian lands, near the Mediterranean coast. Villagers grow dates by the coast in gardens watered by wells and small dams in the wadis that trap run-off from the cliffs during the short rainy season.
Al Hansha
Al Hansha lies near a large coastal sebkha, in the heart of the Tunisian lands. The villagers here, like many neighbouring settlements, grow dates.
Souk Ahras Castle
Bled El Anneb

Bled El Anneb sits on the southern shores of the Mediterranean and is located on the eastern edge of the Edough massif, and to the southeast of the Seybouse wadi which joins the Mediterranean Sea. The climate is well-suited to olive trees that thrive despite the short rainy season.
Tahert Fortress
The waters of Faidj are pure and the soil is fertile, and grain is grown. But a short distance to the south, the land becomes barren and alkaline, and only the hardiest crops survive.
Zagora Fortress

Asfru sits alongside the edge of the Middle Atlas mountains, and the river Oued Aggai runs through it. There is a spring just a short walk outside the village, which the people here believe cures insanity. Villagers trap rainwater and runoff from the hills to water their fields and their gardens of date-palms.
Thar Es-Souk

Thar Es-Souk sits near the source of the river Oued Ouerrha, right where its two smaller streams combine. Villagers sink wells here to tap the stream's groundwater, using it to irrigate their olive groves.
al-Araysh Castle
Afrag sits on the northern tip of Morocco, close to the Gibraltar strait. Villagers scrape clay from the shallow waters to sell to the region's potters.
Beni Barka Castle
The village of Toujane sits in a wadi amid some mesas. The land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grass hills.
Oued Souf

Oued Souf or simply Suf, meaning the River in the Berber languages, is an oasis town watered by an underground river, hence its name. This river enables date palm cultivation. Most of the roofs in this city are domed, thus the city is known as the 'City of a Thousand Domes'.

Degueche began as an oasis exploited since Roman times. The ancient Roman city of Thagis is situated a half days' trek away. It lies on the northern shore of the salt lake Shatu Aljarid. In the spring, it is sometimes possible to catch sight of large, red winged birds that use the shores as nesting sites.
Mih Ouansa
Mih Ouansa lies a couple hours south of the domed city, Oued Souf. The seawinds bring the uplands here just enough rain to support the cultivation of olive trees.
Abu Kammash
Abu Kammash is a small fishing village by the sea. A low reef runs parallel to the shore for about two miles.

Babar sits between the base of two mountains in the Saharan foothills. According to local elders, lions are driven off here with sheep and goats, so that they leave the inhabitants alone. Rainwater trapped in cracks in the rock is diverted to the village's date-palm gardens.
Béchar
Béchar lies elevated on the banks of Oued Béchar, which runs through the city from northeast to southwest. The rocky highlands of the Djebel Béchar overlook the city from the southeast. .
Tahert sits amid open plains and patches of dry acacia forest. Some of Africa's most prized horses graze on the grasses of this district.
Abu Khih sits in the vast Saharan expanse. The surrounding lands, an ancient lakebed, are already becoming barren and alkaline, although date-palms still thrive.
El Ouata

El Ouata lies on the left bank of the Oued Saoura in the Saoura valley. A large area of continuous sand dunes lies to the east, while rocky ridges of the Ougarta mountains rise to the west. The lands directly surrounding the village is mostly desert-steppe. Barren most of the year except for scrub, it is covered in grass and flowers in the spring and is fine grazing for horses.

The city of Marrakech sits in the Tensift River valley, with the river passing along the northern edge of the city. The silvery valley of the Ourika river curves northwards towards Marrakech, and to the south the red heights of the Jebel Yagour are capped with snow all year round. The region has been inhabited by Berber farmers for a multitude of centuries, but the city of Marrakech was founded by the Almoravid Emir Abu Bakr ibn Umar as its capital.

Rahaminah sits about a weeks long voyage from the city of Marrakech. Runoff from the hills is trapped underground here, creating springs that sustain an oasis. Wheat thrives in the fields and gardens.

Souarekh lies near the Mediterranean coast, and just a short walk east of the Lake Tonga. Villagers raise horses here, taking advantage of the brief but lush crop of grass that covers the slopes in the spring.
Al-Burūj
Al-Burūj is situated south of a small lake. Villagers dig down to the shallow groundwater layer for clay to sell to the potters of the Nahasa.

The existence of the town of Tunis is likely centuries old. Situated on a hill, the city serves as an excellent point from which the comings and goings of naval and caravan traffic can be observed. Historically, it was one of the first towns in the region to fall under Carthaginian control.

Zaghouan is situated near the ruins of an old Roman town, which had an aqueduct built that carried water all the way to Carthage but of this aqueduct only ruins remain. The nearby low-lying coastline is well-suited to the construction of salt pans.

Siliana sits near a large, fast flowing river which it shares its name with. The village lies only a couple of hours trek from an old battlefield where Roman forces decisively defeated Carthaginian forces, ending a decades long war. The villagers here sink wells to water their groves of date palms.
Aghdir sits on the river Loukos. The villagers here sink wells to water their groves of date palms.
Dar Allouch

Dar Allouch is a village located on the northeastern end of the Cape of Mercury peninsula, as the Romans named it. Villagers sail out in feluccas to harvest perch that sometimes grow as long as a man is tall, keeping an eye out for the salt-water crocodiles which live in the local inlets and marshes and which compete with them for their catch.

The inland city of Laghouat is an oasis on the north edge of the great Sahara, in the Amour Range of the Saharan Atlas mountains. It is built on the banks of the Wadi Mzee, which flows eastwards from the Amour Range and is one of a large number of seasonal streams that empty into the Chott Melrhir.
Hasi Errmel

Hasi Errmel sits in a broad valley between the hills in the desert steppe south of Laghouat. Groundwater provides just enough water to grow crops for subsistence, while the village makes its money from rearing horses on the rich grass that grows here after the spring rains.
Béni Ounif
Béni Ounif sits in a broad valley southeast of Béchar. Farmland is limited here, and the land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.
Mecif sits by the Shatu Alhadna, a shallow saline lake, in lowlands well suited to the growing of flax.

The coastal city of Dzayer's earliest history was as a small port in the Carthage where Phoenicians traded with other Mediteranneans. The Punic wars saw the town's administration taken over by the Romans. But the present day city was founded by the founder of the Berber Zirid dynasty, Buluggin ibn Ziri.
Akerrou's rich silt deposits left by the river make this one of the most fertile regions of the northern African lands.
The rich silt deposits left by the river make the village of Imsouhal one of the most fertile regions of the North African lands.
Sidi Daoud
Sidi Daoud is a farming hamlet on the west bank of the Sebaou River, just a few miles downstream from its mouth.

Local legend has it that the name of the town was the name of a wealthy woman who was married to a Roman officer. Zenina is a flourishing farmer town, the soil in these lands is refreshed yearly by the silt of the flooding river, producing bountiful crops of wheat.

Zagora sits in the Darha Valley west of the river Darha, which is formed by the confluence of the Dadés and the Imini and is Morocco's longest river. On the base of the mountain on which the town sits is the fortress erected in Almoravid times which is a vital strategic point for the Marinids.
Bir Morra

Bir Morra sits in the rocky wadis at the inland edge of Tūnisia, before it gives way to barren gravel plains and dunes. Clouds from the north drop their last reserves of water here in the spring and winter, giving the land just enough grass to support horse-rearing.
Agadir Tissint
Agadir Tissint, or simply Tissint, sits in the southern wastes of Morocco. Rocky soil in this district limits irrigation, but horses thrive on the spring grasses of the hills.

Tabelbala is an oasis village that occupies a band of land between a stone mountain to the south and a large sand dune field to the north. The water table of this dune field is relatiely high, making irrigation agriculture possible. The villagers here use foggaras to irrigate the wheat and other crops they cultivate.

Imzuren, or Imzouren, sits between the rivers Rhis and Nekor, which flow into the Mediterranean Sea. The village traditionally holds a weekly souk, or market, that sees the gathering of merchants from dozens of neighbouring tribes. The silt brought by the rivers here produces bountiful crops of wheat.
Ribâtu

The city of Ribâtu sits on the Atlantic coast about two hundred miles from The Passage to Europe. The River Bou Regreg meanders through it, originating from the Mechra wadi, and flows out into the Atlantic. The city was founded only a century ago by the Almohads, who built a citadel, a mosque and a residence and was named Ribat which means fortress.
Tifelt sits on the edge of the Gharb plain at about two days trek from Ribâtu. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.
Boujniba, also known as Bu Janiba, sits in the heart of the Moroccan wastesz. Villagers here fish for tuna, sardines, bonito and shark.
Rougemont Castle
The village of Marchia is surrounded by steep hills. It sits at the great road which leads from Langres to Straborc.
Gaillard Castle

Saint-Vaize sits in the warm wooded lands of Aquitane near the meandering Charente river. The land is rich in fertile soil and wheat fields dominate the surrounding hills. There are ruins of a monastery nearby, which was probably dedicated to Vasius, who was a wealthy landowner and martyr of the Catholic Church credited with the founding of Saint-Vaize.
Cauletum sits on the right bank of the meandering river Moine. The villagers grow olives on the warm, dry landward side of the hills.
Éguilly Castle

Essoyes is a quiet village in the County of Champagne, sitting on the banks river Ource, a tributary of the Seine. The village is bound to the Molesme Abbey. The villagers venture out far into the waters to cod-rich banks washed by a cold current from the north.
Hardelot Castle
Guisia sits on the banks of the Aisne, a small and fast-flowing river.
Corlay Castle
Plemelin sits in lowlands of Bretagne, near the coast. The village is surrounded by small streams originating from the River Blavet to the west. The low-lying lands are suited to the growing of flax.

Monteneuc lies between two small streams in the foothills of Bretagne. This area has been inhabited for a long time, as evidenced by a site of megaliths—large stones set upright by ancient peoples and used to construct monuments—in the area.
Raoul Castle
Châtillon-en-Bazois
Châtillon-en-Bazois lies on the L'Aron river. Villagers speak a mix of the Latin, Old French and Germanic tongues. They grow flax in the lowlands here.
Oublanc sits on the river Creuse, a tributary of the Vienne. Villagers here trap beaver and mink in the hills and sometimes pursue seals in the waters of the bay.
The village of Arle sits on the Rhône, close to its mouth where it flows into the Mediterranean Sea. Villagers plant olives here on the hillsides.
Vire Castle

Argentias sits in the heartlands of Normandy. Misty mornings cooled by sea drifting south and warm afternoons make this land well-suited to the growing of grapes, and Argentias is famous for its vineyards.

In Roman times, the city of Lyon was called 'the capital of the Gauls' and by inheritance of this prestigious title, the Archbishop of Lyon is still today styled 'Primate of Gaul'. The city is located in the south-east of France, at the confluence of the rivers Saône and the Rhône and at an important crossroads of Western Europe which connects the North to the Mediterranean Sea, and Eastern Europe to the Atlantic Ocean. It is surrounded by several mountain ranges; the Massif Central to the west and the Alps to the east.
Tournus sits in the Saône valley in the very south of the Duchy of Bourgogne. The people of this district grow flax on the marshy lands.

Champagnole sits in the southwest of the Duchy of Bourgogne, near the German frontier on a low spur just west of the lakes Leman and Neuchâtel. The villagers here grow wheat, finding a ready market in the garrisons stationed nearby.

N'Arbona takes its name from the Celtic or Iberian name 'Narbo', meaning 'dwelling near water' or the name of the Roman god of war Mars. The mines of this district supply the iron ore for many of the forges of the French kingdom.
Bordèu

The city of Bordèu has known status of importance for generations. Under the Romans it was capital of Aquitane Gaul for nearly two centuries, and since the marriage of Eleanor of Aquitane in 1152, it was the capital of the Duchy of Aquitane within the crown of England but since the Treaty of Paris in 1259 its sovereign, as vassal Duke of Guyenne, must pay homage to the king of France. This English possession in mainland France has caused many disputes which oppose the Plantagenets to the kings of France. The town itself is located in the heart of the Aquitane basin.

Austens is situated in southern Aquitane, sitting in marshlands near three large lakes and a dozen smaller lakes. The village is bound to a sizable keep. Villagers harvest the tall trees of the heights, selling the logs to cities on the coast.
Tartas sits on La Midouze, a short tributary river that rushes out of the Adour. The river slows as it hits a nearby bend, allowing the collection of potters' clay from the banks.

Aginnum sits on the central flatlands of Aquitane by the river Garonne, where the milder weather of the French heartland begins to give way to the warmth of the south. Villagers plant flax here amid the bogs and pastures.
Auvers lies in the heart of the Cotentin marshlands in Normandy. Villagers grow wheat and other crops in the silt of the river floodplain.

Metz is by all accounts an ancient vestige of human habitation. It was once a large Celtic settlement, a Gallo-Roman city and the capital of the Kingdom of Austrasia. Metz is also considered the birthplace of the Carolingian dynasty. It is known that the Saint Clement of Metz was the first bishop of Metz, who was sent here by the apostle Saint Peter himself and according to legend slew the dragon Graoully. The city is located on the banks of two rivers, right where they form into many branches.
Mons Barrum
Mons Barrum sits on the river Brenne as it meanders around the village. Villagers plant flax in land reclaimed from the riverside marshes.
Rulund sits in the forested middle valleys of the Trand. The villagers specialize in the raising of hogs, who feast on acorns from the oak woodlands.

Lestines sits on gentle hills in the County of Hennegau near an ancient Roman road that leads to Cöln. Not far from the hamlet is the abbey of Bonne-Espérance which was founded by the famous abbot Hugues de Fosses.

Bologna, in the County of Champagne, sits in a wide meander of the Marne. In the time of the Romans, the village served an important strategic purpose for the local Gauls, as it was situated at the crossroads of a Roman road.

Nantes sits close to the western Atlantic coast of France in Bretagne, on the Loire close to its mouth where it flows into the ocean and at the confluence of the Erdre. During the Gallic period, the region was inhabited by the Namnetes who were ultimately defeated by Caesar and this resulted in the name of the city being latinized to Condevincum. It was not until 1203 that Nantes—and the entirety of Bretagne—came under the domination of the Capetians, specifically the cadet branch of Dreux.
Le Mans

Le Mans is situated in the western lands of the County of Maine on the river Sarthe, a tributary of the Loire. The climate is warm most of the year, and grapes do well on the slopes of the hills of Maine.

Pieric is a fishing village located in the Armorican massif in the Duchy of Bretagne and is characterized by slightly hilly terrain. The hamlet is bordered to the north by the river La Chére which flows eastwards and a smaller stream meanders through the village itself. The villagers work the rivers in search of pike, perch and rarely catfish.

Escouflant sits right by the confluence of the rivers Sarthe and Maine in the central lowlands of the County of Anjou. Villagers here raise sheep on the pastures between the coastal woods and the high crags of the hills.
Orléans

Orléans is the capital of the County of Orléans and is ruled by the Count of Orléans, Prince Philippe of France. The city is located about a hundred miles from Paris, in the Loire Valley on the river Loire which crosses it from east to west. It is thanks to this proximity to the river that the city stands as one of the three richest in all of France. It was in the cathedral of Orléans that the founder of the Capetian dynasty Hugh Capet and his son, Robert, were doubly coronated. For this reason, the County of Orléans is traditionally given to the king's youngest son.
Montargis lies on both banks of the river Loing in the County of Orléans. This village used to be fiefdom of the House of Courtenay until its lands were ceded to the crown of France.
Meinthenon lies in the County of Chartres, in a fertile valley at the confluence of the Eure and the Voise. The climate in these lands are well-suited to the growing of olives.
Poitiers sits at the heart of the County of Poitou, in a low passage between the Armorican Massif and the Massif Central. The relatively warm climate here is well-suited to the cultivation of olives.
Poigniacum sits at the center of the Viscounty of Bourges, surrounded by two small streams. The villagers of this region, like many in the central French kingdom, specialize in the raising of pigs.

The city known today as Marsseille was once a Greek city by the name of Massalia, and its site is largely perceptible even today as it sits on three mounds on a promontory surrounded by the sea. Located in the south-east of the France, Marsseille is almost surrounded with natural defenses; the Mediterranean Sea to the west and south, the mountains Estaque and Etoile to the north, two large massifs to the east, the Mount Puget to the south-east and the Marsseilleveyre massif to the south.
Le Pradet

Le Pradet lies a couple miles east of the city of Marsseille, near the southern French coast. The nearby massifs are covered with cork oaks, umbrella pines and mimosa trees. The presence of numerous streams and the many weeks of annual flooding have always favored the growth of grass and the land is fine pasture for the renowned horses of the French.
The village of Chabuel lies by the meandering river La Véore, a tributary of the Rhône. The village houses a hospital. This warm land is well-suited to the growing of olive trees.

The capital of Paris first appears in writing in Caesar's 'De Bello Gallico' as 'Lutetia'. But the name Paris comes from the Gallic peoples, the Parisii, and the city was once also called Lutetia of the Parisii. The city is located in the heart of a basin with fertile soils and a temperate climate on a loop of the Seine, between its confuences with the Marne and the Oise. Paris was not always the capital of the Kingdom of France, having only gained in importance over time as Robert the Pious restored several abbeys in the city and Louis VI and VII established their court and chancellery here. The city prospered, becoming an important place for trade in wheat, fish and cloth. With the foundation of episcopal schools Paris also became a major center for education. But it was Philippe Auguste who made Paris the undisputed capital of the kingdom, as he was the first of the Capetians to exercise strong control over the city. Today, King Louis further strengthens this control.
Évreux

Évreux lies in the Iton valley in the Duchy of Normandy by a small stream of the same name. Today it is known for its daring fishermen, who venture out far to find banks, chilled by currents from the north, that are rich in cod.

Saint-Saens lies in the Duchy of Normandy on the banks of the Varenne and borders a vast oak forest which was, until the treaty signed in 1259, property of the royal English house of Plantagenet whose members enjoyed hunting here.

Sainte-Menehoste sits far east of the river Marne and borders the river Meuse. Situated in the Duchy of Champagne, the hamlet is surrounded by the marshes formed by the Aisne valley and due to its position on a mound, the current village stands on the site of a former Roman castrum.

The city of Toulouse is the capital of the County of Toulouse and is situated in the south of France, on a bend in the river Garonne which comes from the Pyrenees before it turns in Toulouse towards the Atlantic Ocean. The original Roman city was established on the right bank of Toulouse, on an unsinkable terrace. It is also on this terrace that the merchant and commercial district was formed. The city was once the capital of the Visigothic Kingdom after they had invaded it, but they were eventually driven out again when Clovis conquered the city after defeating them at the Battle of Vouillé.
Sant Flor

Sant Flor sits at the river Ander on its southern banks. The soil here is thin and the weather here is cold, but rich iron deposits sustain the local economy. The settlement is named after Saint Florus, who was an apostle and bishop of Lodéve from Auvergne who, according to legend, was martyred there. His tomb lies in an abbey around which the village developed.
Saint-Simon is located in the County of Auvergne by the fast-flowing river Jordanne, a tributary of the Cére. The peasants here sow wheat and rye in the valley.
Sligigh Castle
Dún Lúiche

Dún Lúiche or Denlewy sits in the valley known as Cró Nimhe, at the foot of the mountain An Earagail and near the shores of the Loch Dhún Lúiche. The village and general region is known for its breeding of excellent ponies known as the Gaelic Hobby, whose quick and agile nature lends itself to extensive use by light cavalry.
Dunnottar Castle
An Duinean
The village of An Duinean or Dunning is centered around the parish church of Saint Serf, on the river Dunning Burn. The villagers are known as skilled pig-farmers.
An Ceathramh Mòr

An Ceathramh Mòr, also known as Kirriemuir, sits at the base of the Angus glens and the landscape is characterized by hills. The lands are not especially fertile here, but pigs thrive in the bush and shrubland of the heights.
Crewkerne Castle

Ileminstre lies by the river Isle, which splits off into numerous streams some of which flow through the village. This location is what gives the village its name, as it means 'The church on the River Isle'. The village was granted by charter to the Abbey of Muchelney by Æthelred the Unready. Miners here have found silver in clefts in the hillsides.
Colchester Castle

The village of Dereham lies in the far east of England, near the coast of the Germanic sea. According to local legend it was here where Saint Withburga, the youngest daughter of King Anna of East Anglia, founded a monastery and a convent after seeing a vision of the Virgin Mary. When she died she was buried in the cemetary of the Ely abbey, but her remains were dug up and found to be incorruptible, thus she was re-interred in the church at Dereham which became a place of pilgrimage. However, this did not please the abbot of Ely and he had elected to steal her body and return it to Ely. The plan worked, and the body was stolen and once again buried at Ely. When the Dereham men had returned to Withburga's tomb and found it violated, they discovered a spring which to this day has never run dry and the village remains a site of pilrimage.
Castlelough Castle
Inis Eonáin

Inis Eonáin, known as Inishannon in English, is a large hamlet situated on the river Brandon at an important crossing point and the area is used as a ferry point on the river. Three years ago, Inishannon was granted a market and fair grant and has seen considerable growth since.
Drumdalege, Droim Dhá Liag in Gaelic, sits humbly near the river Ilen.
Lincoln Castle

The village of Wenflet is only a couple of hours walk from the eastern English coast, by the river Lymn. Wenflet sits on the site of a former Roman settlement, and there are two large burial mounds north and south of here which could either be Roman or made by Danes. The soil is poor but the woods grow thick here, making this the source of much of the timber used in the English lands.
Northalvertune sits near the meandering Willow Beck. Horses are raised on the downs, much prized by both raiders and traders from the Swedish lands to the north.
Dingwall Castle
Forsan Àird

Forsan Áird sits by two small streams that originate from the nearby Halladale River. The people of this region have the reputation of being more focused on trade than warfare, and the elders have encouraged the cultivation of mulberry bushes to sustain a small silk industry.
Lancaster Castle

Christetone, meaning 'Christian's farm', lies on the eastern banks of the River Dee. The people of these parts are foresters, felling the oak, yew and pine of the woods for sale to builders and shipwrights.

The town of Dublind is situated at the mouth of the Ruirthech River. It is bordered by mountains which are called the Dublind Mountains by its locals. To the north and west lie stretches of flat farmland. The town's castle was founded by King Henry's father, John.
Daire Calgaich

'The oak grove of Calgach', sometimes simply called Doire by locals is mostly a monastic village. The hamlet and its surroundings have been inhabited for as long as the populace can remember. Just on the outskirts, the river An Feabhal forms a deep valley and Doire itself is distinctively hilly.
an Óghmaigh
The name an Óghmaigh means 'the virgin plain'. The village is bound to a local monastery which was established in the end of the 8th century.
Cluan Innis
Cluan Innis sits in a nook of the northern banks of the Finn River. There is little to recommend these lands other than the ore deposits in the hills and the bog-iron of the mountain marshes.
Bealach Cláir

The hamlet of Bealach Cláir, whose name means 'pass of the plain', lies in the very northeastern foothills of Ireland. It sits at the 'Six Mile Water' river, which splits off eastwards into a smaller stream. The village has been of strategic importance since the time of the Normans as it has used as crossing point of the river, evidenced by a bridge they erected here.

Glasgu, meaning 'that dear green place', is located on the banks of the River Clyde which has provided a natural location for fishing for centuries of people living there. This is the area the Romans chose for many outpost and ultimately, the erection of the Antonine Wall of which remnants can be found outside the city.
Kilchrenan, or Cill Chrèanain to the scots, lies in the highlands of Scotland near the lake Gealaich which has a few streams that meander towards the village. Villagers here grow grapes for wine.
An Eaglais Bhreac

An Eaglais Bhreac, which the English call Falkirk, is located in the lowlands of Scotland in the Forth valley about a days travel from Glasgu. It is located between the Slamannan Plateau and the Firth of Forth, and two tributaries of the river Carron flow around the village. Remains of the Roman wall can be found here.
Sailcirc, on the Ettrick Water, is a frontier village lying in the Scottish lowlands. The region is known for its production of wheat and barley.
Baile Dhubhthaich
Baile Dhubhthaich lies on rolling downs in the eastern coast of the Scottish highlands on the Dornoch firth. The village specializes in white grapes for the making of sweet wines.

Fincingefelda sits on the green hills north and east of London, in western Essex. The village is a popular stop for travelers traveling from the capital to the town of Northwic. The surrounding farmlands are sown with wheat and barley.

Pembrok sits by the estuary of the river Cleddau, flanked on all sides by woodland and arable farmland. The castle of Pembrok was founded by the Normans in the 11th century and stands at the western tip of the peninsula, surrounded by water on almost all sides.
Y Creunant

Y Creunant, Crynant to the English, sits in a low, forested valley in the south of Wallia. On the eastern banks of the river Dulais, although it gets its name from the smaller stream Creunant that flows just south of here. Villagers trap beavers, foxes and other fur-bearing animals in the dark, marshy woods.

The village of Trawsfynydd is named after the Lake Trawsfynydd on which it was founded. It sits on its eastern shores, and has several streams originating from it meandering past the village. The local parish church here is dedicated to Saint Madryn. The villagers are known for their skill as foresters.

Streford, near the Welsh frontier, sits on the eastern banks of the Quinny Brook river. Villagers harvest the thick-growing forests of oak, yew and beech. The woods here have been tended carefully by the English for centuries, ensuring that there are always enough trees to harvest and sell for timber.
La Medeshole

La Medeshole sits in the plains of Cornwall in the very southwest of the English island. It is surrounded by several small streams. The village boasts a chapel dedicated to Saint Francis, and holds rights to hold an annual market fair on the Feast of Saint Francis, which was granted by King Henry in 1239.

London, the veritable heart of the Kingdom of England. Although the city of Westminster is the true governmental capital, the city of London remains England's largest city and principal commercial centre. The city stands on the river Temese, a navigable river that crosses the city from the south-west to east. Historically, the city grew up at the lowest bridging point of the river but has since far extended.
Walberton sits on the southern coast of England. Villagers mine iron from the hills, for sale to the renowned smiths of nearby London. The village has a church dedicated to Saint Mary.

Kinlet lies on the northern edge of the Wyre Forest, land that historically belongs to the noble family Mortimer who enjoy hunting here. The villagers of these parts tend the forests, harvesting beech, oak and yew for sale to the towns.
Witcherche sits on grassy downs on the river Test, about a four days trek from the capital London. Villagers have planted flax in the boggy dales between the hills.

Derby sits on the river Derwant, on its southern shores in a relatively low-lying area along the river's lower valley, where the south-east foothills of the Pennines adjoin the lowlands. Horses graze above the rapids and waterfalls.

Brunley sits in the north of England in a natural three-forked valley at the confluence of the rivers Brun and Calder, surrounded by open fields, with wild moorland at higher altitudes. The name comes from 'Brun Lea', which means 'meadow by the River Brun'.

Waterford legends speak of the water-nymphs who live in the dark pools under the rock, luring travellers and invaders to their deaths, except on those rare occasions when they fall in love with a hero and grant him victory and blessings. Certainly the fisherfolk of this region have learned respect for the perils of the river Suir, where a small misstep on slippery stone can cast one off a precipice into the waters below.

Wexford sits on the shores of the Irish Channel, right at the mouth of the river Slaney. Villagers scrape mud from the pools and bogs alongside the river as it levels out, carting it up the winding paths to the town of Waterford perched on the cliff above them.
Tiobraid Árann

Also known as Tipperary. In Gaelic, 'Tiobraid Árann' means 'The Well of Ara'—a reference to the River Ara that flows through the town. The village was founded some years ago, and has since become a population centre with plans for fortifications well underway.

Biorra, or Birr, meaning 'plain of water' as the village itself lays near the meeting of the river Camcor and Little Brosna. A small keep is present a short walk outside the village and a popular destination for locals is the monastery founded by Saint Brendan the Elder.
Baile an Locha
Town 'of the lake'. Specifically, the lake O'Flynn which lies north of the village, and is notable for its good fishing of brown trout.
Ostrožac Castle
Počitelj

The hamlet of Počitelj is situated among some freshwater springs. The most interesting of which the villagers have named 'Kipilo'. The villagers, who until recently were nomads, raise sheep known for the long, fine wool.
The village of Podbrdo and its surrounding hamlets lie on the northern side of River Ponor, prime grazing lands for the flocks of the Polish and their principalities.
Galat Castle
Będzin Castle

The village of Predmier is located in the Bytčianska basin. It is surrounded by the river Váh, but a smaller stream flows through the village. The people of these parts have long mined silver from the mountains, a trade that the Polish khans were happy to encourage when they conquered this region.
Bychawa sits near the eastern frontier of the Polish Principalities. This district specializes in the harvest of timber which is floated down the river and sold to the lake towns.
Siklós Castle

Malinovac sits in the lowlands of the eastern Croatian plain. It borders a forest in the south. Though this land is dry most of the year, it experiences winter snowfalls and muddy springs. Fine clay can be collected from the pools left by the snowmelt and the rains.
Eger Castle
Tur lies north of the river Körös. Snow-bound for much of the year, the spring grasses nonetheless sustain sizeable herds of sheep, the thick wool of which protects them from this land's icy winds.

Monok sits in a valley of the Zemplén mountains. On the north and south slopes there are vast fields that can sustain sizeable herds of sheep, the thick wool of which protects them from the icy winds blowing off of the waters.
Sümeg Castle
The hamlet of Csopak sits near the river Vámosi-patak and its lands are mostly owned by the nearby Szentmárton Abbey. Villagers here raise cattle bred to withstand both cold winters and hot summer.
Rupea Castle
Ineu Castle
Plesa is situated just west of the Jiu River in the central plains of Transylvania and villagers here raise herds of cattle bred to withstand the icy winds coming downriver from the north.
Kötegyán
Kötegyán lies on the southeastern edge of the Körös plain. The villagers sow wheat and barley, taking in a good crop before the autumn.

Zenica, the Iron City, lies at the central part of the River Bosna's flow. The city encompasses a valley-basin and is surrounded by hills and the surrounding landscape is characterized by plains, hills and mountain passes.
Brestovac sits alongside the Orljava, a tributary of the Sava river. The spring grasses of this area sustain sizeable herds of sheep, the thick wool of which protects them from this land's icy winds.
Moševac
Moševac sits just west of the Bosna river. The villagers have learned to grow flax in this low-lying marshy land.
Płaska

Płaska sits alongside a collection of lakes. Among those, the largest is the lake Serwy to the west of the village. Though this valley is snowbound for much of the year, ponies thrive on the spring grasses and in the winter dig through the snow for food, their thick coats protecting them from the icy blasts of wind.
Šarbanovac
Šarbanovac sits on the banks of the Šarbanovac river. The village is surrounded by small hills and the villagers raise horses in the lower slopes.
Tîrgoviste
Skawica
Skawica lies in a valley right on the border of two mountain ranges. Until recently, this land was dominated by nomads, and the people here still make their living by raising sheep.

Pyrzyce sits east of the river Oder and just south of the lake Miedwie. The mild climate and fertile soils of the surrounding area enable good harvests, which have helped the city develop over the years. The city has seen major renovations only some twenty years ago, to have it modeled more like its contemporary Western European cities.
Rakoniewice is located in the Greater Poland region. The village makes its living from mining nearby salt deposits.
The hamlet of Brzeziny sits near a small lake. The reddish streaks in the soil and rocks testify to rich iron deposits, which are mined by the villagers.
Pęczniew

The fishing village of Pęczniew sits on the river Pichna and on the shore of a large lake known as the Jeziorsko. The villagers set nets in the river to catch a variety of fish migrating to and from the lake.

The town of Warszewa, in the lowlands of Masovia, sits in the middle course of the Vistula River, slightly elongated along its banks. Bolesława Krzywoustego's district division of Poland—which was supposed to stop the power struggles between his sons—is probably the reason why the town of Warszewa was founded.
Hrastovac sits at the shores of the Vuka River. Villagers go to the nearby woods to harvest one of the Devseg's few sources of timber.
Suraż
Suraż is situated in the eastern frontier marshes of the Polish lands. Villagers, who not long ago still lived a nomadic lifestyle, specialize in the rearing of horses.
Drelów
Drelów sits at the eastern borders of the principalities. Villagers, who not long ago still lived a nomadic lifestyle, raise sheep in the foothills.

The village of Kurzeszyn lies at about a days voyage from Warszewa. Villagers raise cattle here that are bred to withstand both the hot summers and freezing winters. A small, wooden fortification is planned to be built here.
Gradec sits on the southern slopes of the Medvednica mountain and on the banks of the river Sava. The founding of the city of Gradec is linked to the foundation of the diocese in Kaptol, in 1094.
Loitzmannsdorf is a village at the center of a wheat-growing district on a narrow stretch of plain between the Rax mountain range and Lake Neusiedl, which the Germans call the Neusiedler Sea.
Goričan
Goričan is a village on a rocky spur just south-west of the river Mur, or Mura. The villagers here make most of their income from the raising of sheep.
Bačkovica
Bačkovica sits in the Croatian heartlands. This village and its surrounding lands is fine country for wheat.
Kraków

The town of Kraków is located in the south of the principalities of Poland on the Vistula River on the mouths of many of its tributaries, surrounded by forests and situated at the crossroads of many trade routes. In 1241, the city was detroyed during the Mongol invasion and subsequently rebuilt and, in 1257, it was granted a location privilege under the Magdeburg law by Duke Bolesław V. Today, Kraków is mostly inhabited by settlers from Silesia and Germany, which means the townspeople mostly speak German.
Plášťovce

Plášťovce lies in a small valley and is surrounded by several hills on all sides. The villagers here buy horses from the wandering tribes, and raise some of their own, making this the source for many of the steeds ridden by the cavaliers of Eastern Europe.
Pleśna
Pleśna sits in the valley of the Biała river at the mouth of the Pleśnianka stream, and is surrounded by a collection of hills. The villagers here raise sheep like their ancestors.
Piwniczna lies on the Poprad River. The villagers of these parts extract salt from the bitter waters.
Lepsény

Lepsény lies only walking distance from the giant Lake Balaton, which is probably why the area has been inhabited for a long time. In fact, it is known that the surrounding area was inhabited by Roman settlers, as ruins of their houses can be found whichever way one treks.
Seaside Hideout
al-Qāhirah
Médinet el-Fayoum
Asyūt
Ezbet Abou Saeda
Al Wasta
Ras Gharib
Awlad Salamah
al-Iskandarīyah
Dar as Salam
Zintan Castle
Sebha Castle
El Tag Castle
El Tag
Harat Zuwayyah
Binġāzī
Bi'r bin Ghunayma
Saùnnu
Siwa Castle
Ezbet Shaalan
Qena Castle
El Qousseir
an-Nekhel Fortress
Izbat at Tawabrah
al-Mouwaylih Castle
Al Wajh
al-Madīna
Djeddah Castle
Ma'arrat al-Numan
Abou Douhour
Lattaquié
Ravanda Castle
Rozafa Castle
Témenos Castle
Spárti

Corenia is one of the farthest flung villages of the empire to speak the Calradic tongue. It sits in the plains southeast of Lake Tanaesis in the shadow of the Akkan Hills, beyond which is spoken only Darshi and the languages of the steppe. Villagers grow grain here, keeping watch for raiders from across the frontiers.
Réthymnon

Metachia is the lies on the southern shores of Lake Tanaesis in the frontier lands beyond River Tiagys. This imperial colony, established in more peaceful times, is a center for mulberry bushes used in silk production.
Atikhisar Castle

Melion in a narrow valley near the center of the Myzead, a rugged plateau in the east of the Empire. Villagers here cultivate mulberry bushes. The leaves are harvested and fed to silkworks, producing thread much valued by both refined imperial nobles for their courtwear and hard-riding nomads and frontiersmen, who wear it beneath their armor as an extra layer of protection against arrows.

Sagolina sits at the foot of a narrow valley in the Myzead, a rugged plateau in eastern Calradia. The silver mined from nearby hills helps explain the effort and expense to which the Empire has gone in past centuries to conquer and defend these lands.
Akrotori Castle
Limassol Castle
Zela Castle
Kır Şehri

Sestadaim sits on the western side of the great Ornian rock, an outcrop in the center of the Lycarea valley. Some say the vultures for which the rock is named once gathered here to feast on the bodies of those who died working the local silver mines.
Erzurum Castle
Bingöl
Van Fortress
Chanopsis sits near the headwaters of the Sethys river in the plateau region known as the Myzead. Wheat grows well on the sun-baked plains.
Sérrai
Komotiní
Aráchova
Kōnstantinoúpolis
Kándora
Şanlıurfa
Kara Hissar
Ánkyra
Suşehri
The Retreat
